title-group.article-title: A multicenter randomized controlled clinical pilot study of buccally micro‐veneered lithium‐disilicate and zirconia crowns supported by titanium base abutments: 1‐year outcomes

aff.named-content: Division of Fixed Prosthodontics and Biomaterials
aff.institution: University Clinic of Dental Medicine, University of Geneva

aff.named-content: Clinic of Preventive Dentistry, Periodontology and Cariology, and Clinic of General, Special Care and Geriatric Dentistry, Center of Dental Medicine
Division of Prosthodontics, Faculty of Dental Medicine

author-notes.corresp: *Correspondence Malin Strasding, Division of Fixed Prosthodontics and Biomaterials, University Clinics of Dental Medicine, University of Geneva, 1 Michel‐Servet, CH‐1211 Geneva, Switzerland. Email: malin.strasding@unige.ch

license.license-p: This is an open access article under the terms of the http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-nc-nd/4.0/ License, which permits use and distribution in any medium, provided the original work is properly cited, the use is non‐commercial and no modifications or adaptations are made.

sec.title: Objectives
sec.p: To investigate survival rates, technical and biologic outcomes of buccally micro‐veneered all‐ceramic single implant crowns.

sec.title: Material and Methods
sec.p: Sixty subjects randomly received immediately or early placed implants. Crowns out of lithium‐disilicate (n = 30) and zirconia‐ceramic (n = 30) were bonded to titanium‐base‐abutments. Restorations were inspected at baseline (BL) and during follow‐up visits (6, 12 months). Technical and biologic parameters were recorded. Data were analysed descriptively. Differences between groups were tested with Student's t‐test. Paired T‐test was used when comparing data from the same implant or tooth over time. Linear model repeated measures were used to test differences between materials over time. Differences in counts were evaluated using Pearson Chi‐square test. The level of significance was at p < .05.

sec.title: Results
sec.p: After a mean observation time of 13.2 ± 2.4 months, 54 restorations were re‐examined. The implant survival rate was 98.3%, and the restoration survival rate was 100%. One early implant failure occurred. Two minor chippings occurred in lithium‐disilicate restorations. No chippings or fractures occurred in any zirconia restorations at 1 year (0%). The technical complication rate was 3.7%, with 7.7% complications among the lithium‐disilicate restorations and no differences between the two materials (p = .558). At 1‐year follow‐up, mean Bleeding on Probing (BOP) was higher at implants (0.27 ± 0.3) than adjacent teeth (0.17 ± 0.18) (p = .046) with no differences between materials (p = .36). Differences in pocket probing depth (PPD) between implants and adjacent teeth were significant (p < .01). Jemt Index improved significantly from BL to 1‐y‐follow‐up (p < .001).

sec.title: Conclusions
sec.p: Preliminary results were good, suggesting that the ceramic type does not impact technical and biologic parameters.

p.mixed-citation: Strasding, M., Hicklin, S. P., Todorovic, A., Fehmer, V., Mojon, P., & Sailer, I. (2023). A multicenter randomized controlled clinical pilot study of buccally micro‐veneered lithium‐disilicate and zirconia crowns supported by titanium base abutments: 1‐year outcomes. Clinical Oral Implants Research, 34, 56–65. 10.1111/clr.14018 36321877

sec.title: INTRODUCTION
sec.p: In recent years, a shift from metal‐ceramic to all‐ceramic materials for single implant restorations has occurred (Edelhoff et al., 2019a; Edelhoff et al., 2019b). Due to the fast‐paced development of digital technologies and new ceramic materials with improved mechanical and aesthetic properties, today, there is a broad range of material choices for implant‐borne restorations (Beuer et al., 2008). High chipping rates of metal‐ceramic and all‐ceramic single crowns (SC) (at 5 years: 2.8%–11.8%) and multiple fixed dental prostheses (FDPs) (at 5 years: 11.6%–50% in one small study) led to the need for improved mechanical properties and new designs for ceramic restorations (Pjetursson, Valente, et al., 2018; Rabel et al., 2018; Sailer, Strasding, et al., 2018). Monolithic design of single and multiple‐unit restorations show promising short‐ and mid‐term results (significantly less annual chipping rates of monolithic zirconia SC of 0.39% compared to 1.65% annual chipping rates for veneered SC; p = .017) (Pjetursson et al., 2021) and may potentially reduce mechanical complications in the long term (De Angelis et al., 2020; Pjetursson et al., 2021; Pjetursson, Valente, et al., 2018; Sailer, Strasding, et al., 2018; Strasding et al., 2018). Recent systematic reviews state the need for more clinical studies on the long‐term behavior of these monolithic ceramics, anticipating a significant reduction in chipping rates (Conejo et al., 2017; Pjetursson, Valente, et al., 2018; Rabel et al., 2018; Sailer, Strasding, et al., 2018). For aesthetic reasons, a completely monolithic design is not indicated in all clinical situations. Therefore, a buccal cut‐back and application of aesthetic veneering ceramic in the visible areas are proposed (Marchack et al., 2011). The application of buccal veneering ceramic was reduced to non‐functional regions to limit the risks of chipping of the veneering ceramic. Recently, this minimal buccal veneering technique with ≤0.5 mm veneering in solely non‐functional areas was defined as micro‐veneering (Pjetursson et al., 2021).

In addition to the developments of crown materials and designs, changes have also occurred on the abutment level. Traditionally, restorations were either directly screw‐retained using an intermediate abutment or cemented onto prefabricated or customized titanium or zirconia abutments (Pjetursson, Zarauz, et al., 2018; Wittneben et al., 2017; Zarauz et al., 2020). Using a customized metal or ceramic abutments, high aesthetic results can be achieved (Zembic et al., 2015), but this solution is costly and may therefore not be affordable for many patients (Joda & Bragger, 2016).

The titanium base concept has evolved during the last years, allowing a completely digital workflow and a monolithic restoration design (Edelhoff et al., 2019b; Pitta et al., 2018). This leads not only to reduced costs but also to a more time‐efficient workflow (Joda & Bragger, 2016; Pan et al., 2019). Manufacturers developed a variety of titanium bases, onto which the monolithic restorations are bonded before intraoral insertion by screwing the one‐piece restoration onto the implant (Pitta et al., 2019). This new design is referred to in the literature as a hybrid abutment crown (Edelhoff et al., 2019b; Pitta et al., 2021). Several in vitro studies investigated the mechanical behavior of ceramic hybrid abutment crowns bonded onto titanium bases and proposed bonding protocols (Nouh et al., 2019; Pitta et al., 2020; Pitta et al., 2021; Zahoui et al., 2020). One research group suggested lithium‐disilicate crowns bonded to titanium bases as an alternative to the traditional porcelain‐fused‐to‐metal (PFM) ‐ gold abutment‐based implant restorations. In contrast, the authors raised concerns regarding the long‐term stability of the bonded interface between the titanium base and the ceramic hybrid abutment crowns (Pitta et al., 2021). In comparison to lithium‐disilicate, zirconia presented a higher incidence of complications. The authors explained this by the mechanical and bonding properties of the zirconia (Pitta et al., 2021). On the clinical level, only scarce data are available regarding this newly developed concept (Conejo et al., 2017; De Angelis et al., 2020).

For the present randomized controlled clinical trial, bone‐level tapered implants (BLT) with a novel root‐shaped, tapered design were inserted. The study aimed to investigate the survival rate and clinical outcomes of implant‐borne CAD/CAM, buccally micro‐veneered single crowns out of two different all‐ceramic materials bonded onto titanium base abutments. The primary outcome of this study was the survival of the buccally micro‐veneered all‐ceramic restorations. Secondary outcomes were technical and biological outcomes of the restorations.

sec.title: Study design and subjects
sec.p: The present study reports on the 1‐year outcomes of a 5‐year parallel, multicenter randomized controlled clinical trial (clinical trial period: 2015–2020). The study was performed according to the current version of the World Medical Association (WMA) Declaration of Helsinki (amended by the 64th WMA General Assembly 2013) and in compliance with ICH‐GCP guidelines and ISO 14155, and in compliance with CONSORT guidelines for randomized trials. The study was registered in the US clinical trials register (NCT05079542). Ethical approval was obtained by the local ethical committee (CCER 15‐117) before the initiation of the study. All included subjects signed informed consent.

Subjects for this study were recruited at the University Dental Clinic of Geneva, Switzerland, and in four associated swiss private dental offices (Private dental offices: LB, Lausanne; RJ, La Chaux‐de‐Fonds; PR, Morges; FM, Genève) (Table 1).

caption.p: Distribution of study groups to university and private dental office

sec.p: A sample size calculation could not be performed at the initiation of the study, as no scientific data for the new, bone‐level tapered implant design used in this study existed. Further, no clinical data on all‐ceramic, buccally micro‐veneered crowns bonded to titanium base abutments was available. Hence, the study was designed as a pilot randomized controlled clinical trial (RCT) with a sample of 60 subjects.

Sixty subjects in need of a single implant‐borne restoration in the maxillary or mandibular anterior or premolar region were included in the study. Twenty‐one subjects were treated in the four associated private dental offices, while 39 subjects were treated at the Geneva University Clinics of Dental Medicine. The requirement was that the tooth/root extraction be performed after study inclusion. Furthermore, subjects had to be in good general health, >22 years old, and capable of providing written informed consent. Bone quality and quantity had to be adequate for one‐stage implant placement. Bone height had to be at least 1 mm longer than the length of the study implant. Subjects were excluded from the study in case of pronounced esthetic expectations, thin mucosal biotype, lack of keratinized mucosa (<2 mm), a high smile line, severe bruxism, insufficient oral hygiene, and excessive smoking (>10 cigarettes/day). Also, women with positive urine pregnancy tests were excluded from participation. Subjects with mucosal diseases, systemic diseases, or a history of antiresorptive agents were also excluded. Further exclusion criteria were alcohol or drug abuse.

All subjects received one bone level tapered implant (BLT Roxolid SLActive implants, Institut Straumann AG, Basel, Switzerland) with implant diameters of either 3.3 or 4.1 mm; and implant lengths of 8, 10, 12, or 14 mm. Implants were non‐submerged during the healing phase, and all‐ceramic crowns were inserted to replace maxillary or mandibular incisors, canines, or premolars. The recruited subjects received one out of four treatment modalities depending on the randomization. Randomization was performed by assigning the 60 subjects to a randomly generated list of numbers from 1 to 4 (study groups) according to their sequence of inclusion. This assignment was performed by a third person (SG), not involved in the study:
Group 1: Immediate implant placement, immediately after tooth extraction + buccally micro‐veneered hybrid abutment crown made from lithium‐disilicate glass–ceramic (E.max CAD, Ivoclar Vivadent AG), bonded to a titanium base abutment (Variobase for Cerec, Institut Straumann AG) (IP‐LD).
Group 2: Early implant placement, 6–8 weeks after tooth extraction + buccally micro‐veneered hybrid abutment crown made from lithium‐disilicate glass–ceramic (E.max CAD, Ivoclar Vivadent AG), bonded to a titanium base abutment (Variobase for Cerec, Institut Straumann AG) (EP‐LD).
Group 3: Immediate implant placement, immediately after tooth extraction + buccally micro‐veneered hybrid abutment crown made from densely sintered zirconia (Lava Plus, 3 M Schweiz GmbH), bonded to a titanium base abutment (Variobase for Cerec, Institut Straumann AG) (IP‐Z).
Group 4: Early implant placement, 6–8 weeks after tooth extraction + buccally micro‐veneered hybrid abutment crown out of densely sintered zirconia (Lava Plus, 3 M Schweiz GmbH), bonded to a titanium base abutment (Variobase for Cerec, Institut Straumann AG, Basel, Switzerland) (EP‐Z).

It was recorded whether subjects received an additional minor xenogenic bone contour augmentation utilizing guided bone regeneration (GBR) technique or not. Implant stability was evaluated through Implant Stability Quotient (ISQ)‐measurements at implant placement and over time until crown insertion. Five weeks after implant surgery, conventional impressions were made of vinyl polysiloxane impression material (Express, 3M Schweiz GmbH), and master casts were poured with a type‐4 plaster. These models were then scanned with a laboratory scanner (inEos X5, Dentsply Sirona), and the standard transformation language (STL) data were used for the digital design of the restorations with laboratory software (Cerec in‐lab 16.1, Dentsply Sirona). Eight weeks after implant surgery, subjects received a hybrid abutment crown, corresponding to an early loading protocol. The crowns were made either out of lithium‐disilicate glass–ceramic with a flexural strength of 530 MPa (E.max CAD, Ivoclar Vivadent AG) or out of densely sintered zirconia with a flexural strength of >1200 MPa (Lava Plus, 3M Schweiz GmbH), depending on the randomization. Crowns were then bonded onto a titanium base abutment (Variobase for Cerec, Institut Straumann AG). All titanium base abutments had the same dimensions with 1 mm gingiva height (GH). All restorations were fabricated by one master dental technician (VF). The lithium‐disilicate crowns were milled using a 4‐axis milling machine (Cerec inLab MC XL, Sirona). The densely sintered zirconia crowns were milled using a 5‐axis milling machine (Wieland Zenotec Select Hybrid, Wieland Dental & Technik GmbH). The crowns' functional incisal/occlusal aspect was milled fully anatomical in a monolithic design. The crowns were then fit onto the laboratory analogs and inserted into the cast models. For aesthetic reasons, a buccal micro‐veneering (0.4–0.7 mm) was performed on the facial aspect of the restorations through a slight facial cut back designed before milling and subsequently manually added fluorapatite glass–ceramic (IPS e.max Ceram; Ivoclar Vivadent). After that, the restorations were put into a sintering furnace for firing. Before the bonding process, the titanium base abutments were sandblasted with 50 μm Al2O3, then thoroughly cleaned in an ultrasonic bath and afterwards, a universal primer (Monobond Plus; Ivoclar Vivadent) was applied for 60 s, then blow‐dried with air.(Pitta et al., 2020) Lithium‐disilicate crowns were acid‐etched for 20 seconds with hydrofluoric acid (HF 5%) (IPS Ceramic Etching Gel, Ivoclar Vivadent AG). Before bonding, densely sintered zirconia crowns were sandblasted (50 μm Al2O3). Both crown types were adhesively bonded (Multilink Hybrid Abutment HO‐O; Ivoclar Vivadent AG) to the titanium base abutments. The restorations were then screwed onto the implants and tightened with 35 Ncm (baseline). A standardized radiograph and an alginate impression were taken after insertion of the restoration. After 1–3 weeks, a re‐tightening (35 Ncm) of the screw was performed, and the screw access hole was closed with a Teflon strip and composite resin. Then, a silicone impression (Express, 3M Schweiz GmbH) of the restoration, the surrounding tissues, and the adjacent teeth was taken. Follow‐up visits were performed 6 and 12 months after the baseline visit. A standardized radiograph, clinical photographs, and an alginate impression were taken at each follow‐up visit.

All restorations were inspected visually with magnifying glasses, a clinical dental probe, and a dental mirror to detect chippings, cracks, or fractures of the ceramics or any other technical complications such as screw loosening or screw fracture and loss of retention. The clinical evaluation of the integrity of the restorations was performed according to the modified US Public Health Service (USPHS) criteria (Cvar & Ryge, 2005). The following technical complications were documented and reported: minor crack or fracture of the framework or veneering ceramic = intraorally polishable, not presenting any functional or esthetic compromises for the patient and therefore no replacement needed; major fracture of the framework or veneering ceramic = not polishable, an adjustment in the dental laboratory required; or fractures of restorations, which needed replacement. Loss of retention was examined by verifying whether a debonding of the restoration from the titanium base abutment had occurred. Further, it was verified whether the prosthetic screw had loosened or not or if a screw fracture had occurred.

Additionally, biological parameters were recorded: Bleeding on Probing (BOP) at the implant site and adjacent teeth (mean BOP of 4 measured locations per site), Plaque Index (PI) at the implant site and adjacent teeth (mean PI of 4 measured areas per site), Pocket Probing Depth (PPD) at four sites per implant site and adjacent teeth (highest value per implant/tooth was taken for statistical analysis), the width of Keratinized Mucosa (KM) at the implant site and adjacent teeth, and papilla fill as Jemt Index (Jemt, 1997) between implant site and adjacent teeth (the lower of the two values per implant site was considered for statistical analysis).

sec.title: Definitions
sec.p: Implant survival: all implants are functional and in situ at the 1‐year follow‐up visit.
Restoration survival: all restorations in place at the 1‐year follow‐up visit, even if complications had occurred during the follow‐up period, as long as the restoration had not been replaced.

Complication‐free restorations: all restorations that did not show any complications and were neither modified nor repaired at the 1‐year follow‐up visit. Any modification or repair was counted as a complication.

sec.title: Statistical analysis
sec.p: The data were analysed using SPSS statistical package (IBM® SPSS Statistics version 26 (IBM corp.)). Records taken at several sites per tooth or implant were averaged to obtain one value for each tooth or implant. Kolmogorov–Smirnov tests showed slight but significant deviations from a normal distribution for many parameters. Hence, differences between groups were tested using the Student's t‐test since it is robust to a slight departure from normality. Paired T‐test was used when comparing data from the same implant or tooth over time (Strasding et al., 2020). When normal distribution was observed, a general linear model (repeated measures) was used to test differences between materials and over time. Differences in counts, such as the number of chipping, were evaluated using the Pearson Chi‐square test.

sec.title: RESULTS
sec.p: Sixty subjects, 27 female (45%), with a mean age of 56.6 ± 12.9 years, were included in the study. Fifty subjects (83.3%) were non‐smokers. All 60 subjects received one Bone‐Level Tapered (BLT) implant (implants dimensions see Tables 2 and 3). Maxillary premolars (48.4%), maxillary central incisors (21.6%), and maxillary lateral incisors (13.3%) were the most frequently replaced teeth, followed by maxillary canines (8.3%) and mandibular premolars (8.3%).

Fifty‐nine subjects received 59 all‐ceramic screw‐retained Single Crowns (SCs). One subject experienced an early implant failure of an immediately placed implant to replace the left first premolar in the upper jaw, with a diameter of 4.1 mm and a length of 12 mm, and did therefore not receive the restoration and was hence considered as an early dropout. Besides the early loss of the implant mentioned above, no further problems with the implants were found throughout the 1‐year follow‐up period. Hence, the implant's 1‐year survival rate was 98.3%.

Two different ceramic restoration materials were randomly assigned to the 59 subjects, equally distributed. Twenty‐nine subjects received lithium‐disilicate crowns, and 30 subjects received densely sintered zirconia crowns bonded to titanium bases. (See Figure 1).

After a mean observation time of 13.2 ± 2.4 months, 54 subjects with 54 implant‐borne SCs were clinically and radiographically re‐examined. Five subjects did not attend the 1‐year follow‐up visit. Three subjects could no longer be reached, and two subjects were temporarily non‐available but returned for later follow‐up visits.

None of the examined restorations was lost, resulting in a prosthetic survival rate of 100%. Out of the implant‐borne SCs examined at 1 year, 26 restorations were out of lithium‐disilicate (E.max CAD, Ivoclar Vivadent AG), and 28 restorations were out of densely sintered zirconia (Lava Plus, 3M Schweiz GmbH, Rüschlikon, Switzerland). (See Figure 1).

sec.title: Technical outcomes
sec.p: Three minor chippings of the micro‐veneering occurred in one zirconia‐ and two lithium‐disilicate ceramic restorations in one maxillary canine, one maxillary, and one mandibular premolar during the follow‐up. One of the minor chippings was already detected at the final closure of the screw access hole 2 weeks after crown insertion. The other two minor chippings were detected at 6 months. All chippings were located at the transition of the buccal to the incisal/occlusal aspect of the restorations (Figure 2a–d) and were intraorally polished. Unfortunately, one of the three patients mentioned above with minor chipping at the six‐month follow‐up did not attend the 12‐month follow‐up visit and was, therefore, counted as a dropout. No other technical complications, such as loss of retention (debonding, cementation gaps, screw‐loosening) or screw fractures, occurred during the first year.

caption.p: (a–d) Clinical pictures of occurred chipping. (a) Clinical picture of occurred buccal chipping on a maxillary premolar, occlusal view. (b) Clinical picture of occurred chipping on incisal edge of a maxillary canine, incisal view. (c) Clinical picture of occurred chipping on incisal edge of a maxillary canine, buccal view. (d) Clinical picture of occurred buccal chipping on mandibular premolar, occlusal view.

sec.p: Hence, at 1 year, the overall technical complication rate was 3.7%, with a complication rate of 0% for zirconia restorations and a complication rate of 7.7% for lithium‐disilicate restorations. There were no significant differences in outcomes/complication rates between the two restoration materials (p = .558).

sec.title: Bleeding on probing (BOP)
sec.p: No significant difference in BOP was found between the ceramic materials between baseline and 6‐month follow‐up, and between baseline and 1‐year follow‐up (p = .36; Table 4). However, a significant decrease in BOP was found on the adjacent teeth between baseline and 1‐year follow‐up (p = .013). This difference was not significant at 6‐month follow‐up.

caption.p: BOP median and interquartile ranges. The BOP is close to zero and according to the median value it does not vary over time.

sec.p: At baseline, no significant difference was found between BOP at implant sites (mean BOP for four measured values per site): 0.3 ± 0.3 and BOP at adjacent teeth (mean BOP: 0.24 ± 0.27; p = .193). At the 1‐year follow‐up examination, BOP was significantly higher at implant site (mean BOP: 0.27 ± 0.30) than at adjacent teeth (mean BOP: 0.17 ± 0.18; p = .046).

sec.title: Plaque index (PI)
sec.p: No significant differences in PI could be measured between lithium‐disilicate ‐ and zirconia restorations (p = .467; Table 5). There was a small increase in PI at implant site between BL (mean PI of 0.02 ± 0.07) and 1‐year follow‐up (mean PI of 0.07 ± 0.18; p = .04). The overall PI did not change significantly at the adjacent teeth between BL (mean PI of 0.16 ± 0.15) and 1‐year follow‐up (0.17 ± 0.2; p = .77).

sec.title: Pocket probing depth (PPD)
sec.p: According to the general linear model (repeated measures) PPD values did not show any significant differences between the groups lithium‐disilicate versus zirconia, and over time (p > .05; Figure 3). The mean PPD at the implant site (BL) was 3.5 ± 0.7 mm, and at 1 year, 3.6 ± 0.8 mm. PPD was 2.4 ± 0.4 mm (BL) and 2.3 ± 0.5 mm (1 year) at adjacent teeth. Differences in PPD between implant sites and adjacent teeth were significant both at BL and at 1 year (p < .01).

caption.p: Changes in mean pocket probing depth (PPD) over time (BL to 12 months).

sec.title: Keratinized mucosa (KM)
sec.p: No significant differences were found between the two ceramic materials (mean KM lithium‐disilicate: 3.3 ± 1.0 mm; mean KM zirconia: 3.8 ± 1.5 mm; p = .943; Figure 4).

caption.p: Changes in mean keratinized mucosa (KM) over time (BL to 12 months).

sec.p: KM had mean values of 3.4 ± 1.5 mm (BL), and 3.6 ± 1.3 mm (1 year). There were no significant differences in KM between the implant site and the adjacent teeth at baseline, 6 months, and 1‐year follow‐up.

sec.title: Jemt Index
sec.p: There was no significant difference in the Jemt Index between the two ceramic materials at 1‐year follow‐up (p = .128) (Figure 5).

caption.p: Changes in mean Jemt Index over time (BL to 12 months).

sec.p: At baseline, the Jemt Index showed a mean value of 1.6 ± 0.6; at 6 months, the mean Jemt Index was 1.9 ± 0.6, and at the 1‐year follow‐up, the mean Jemt Index was 2.0 ± 0.6. The values changed significantly between baseline and 6‐month follow‐up (p = .001) and between baseline and 1‐year follow‐up (p < .001), whereas the change in Jemt Index was not significant between 6‐months and 1‐year follow‐up (p = .439), but showed a tendency to increase over time.

sec.title: DISCUSSION
sec.p: The 1‐year results of this multicenter practice‐based RCT showed very promising survival rates of 100% and low complication rates of 3.7% of buccally micro‐veneered monolithic all‐ceramic restorations supported by titanium base abutments. Chipping of the buccal micro‐veneering was the only technical problem. No statistically significant differences were found between the two restorative materials. Nevertheless, a trend of slightly more chipping of 7.7% in lithium‐disilicate restorations than in zirconia restorations with 0% chipping at 1‐year follow‐up could be observed. Although chippings were detected, they were solely analyzed intraorally. No in‐depth analysis of the location and extension of the chipping could be performed under a scanning electron microscope (SEM) due to study protocol reasons (no removal of restoration during study observation time). Therefore, it remains unknown whether the chipping occurred within the veneering ceramic or between framework and veneering ceramic. This question should be further analysed in future research.

Until today, the significant problems of tooth‐ and implant‐borne metal‐ceramic and all‐ceramic restorations are chipping and fracture of the veneering ceramics (Pjetursson, Valente, et al., 2018; Strasding et al., 2020). Systematic reviews focused on different restoration materials and designs, comparing metal‐ceramic and different all‐ceramic designs. These reviews have shown that chipping remains the major technical complication for implant‐borne single‐ and multiple‐unit restorations (Abou‐Ayash et al., 2017; Pjetursson, Valente, et al., 2018; Sailer, Strasding, et al., 2018). The main limitation of these reviews is the lack of RCTs addressing the focused question, which may negatively affect the level of evidence (Abou‐Ayash et al., 2017; Pjetursson, Valente, et al., 2018). Also, overall conclusions were based on the results of pooled data due to a lack of homogeneous study designs and standardized reporting on complications (Pjetursson, Valente, et al., 2018). One major conclusion of the reviews was that there is a need for medium‐ to long‐term data to define indications and limitations for different restoration designs, especially for the new, completely monolithic approach (Pjetursson, Valente, et al., 2018).

Another recent systematic review, which focused only on veneered and monolithic all‐ceramic implant‐supported single crowns, stated that chipping of the veneering ceramic remains one of the critical concerns for implant‐supported single crowns (Pjetursson et al., 2021). An overall annual complication rate of 4.2% for all‐ceramic implant‐supported SCs was estimated. The review reported a short mean follow‐up period of only 1.6 years for monolithic zirconia restorations (Pjetursson et al., 2021). The overall restoration complication rate of 3.7% in the present study is in line with the findings of this latest systematic review. The complication rate of veneered lithium‐disilicate crowns (7.7%) in this study was higher than in the systematic review (2.6% annual complication rate for veneered‐reinforced glass–ceramic SCs) for veneered‐reinforced glass‐ceramics but lower for veneered zirconia SCs (0%) compared to the systematic review (4.5%). The authors of the systematic review found significantly higher chipping rates for veneered SCs (3.9%) (all types of veneering design) in comparison to monolithic SCs (1.8%) (p = .061) (Pjetursson et al., 2021). These results suggest that any kind of ceramic veneering is prone to lead to more technical complications than the completely monolithic approach. In the present study, and until now, the chipping rates of lithium‐disilicate ceramics were low and did not make a significant difference to the zirconia ceramic material. It will be interesting to follow‐up the subjects on a long‐term scale to control if differences in chipping rates between materials occur, and if so, then analyse scientifically due to which reason a chipping rate may be higher in one material compared to the other. According to literature, higher chipping rates would have rather been expected in the zirconia ceramic group, but this was not the case in the present study (Pjetursson et al., 2021; Sailer, Balmer, et al., 2018).

In the future, the monolithic design is proposed as a promising technique to improve technical outcomes further and reduce chipping rates in the future (Pjetursson et al., 2021; Sailer, Strasding, et al., 2018). Nevertheless, it is yet too early to draw conclusions on the long‐term success of monolithic implant restorations.

Even though a monolithic design may be advantageous regarding technical complications, this approach can be contra‐indicated in highly aesthetic regions, where facial veneering is often needed to overcome the aesthetic limitations of monolithic ceramic ingots. To reduce chipping rates in these situations, partial‐coverage veneering, also referred to as micro‐veneering, was evaluated in the recent systematic review (Pjetursson et al., 2021; Rammelsberg et al., 2020; Wittneben et al., 2020). Within the scope of the recent European Association for Osseointegration (EAO) consensus conference, authors defined micro‐veneered all‐ceramic restorations as solely in non‐functional areas minimally veneered restorations (≤0.5 mm) (Pjetursson et al., 2021). The veneering designs in the four studies included in the “micro‐veneered” group of this review differed from each other. Not all studies reported precisely on the veneering extension and thickness, although these details may influence the outcomes. This indicates a need for more standardized definitions of “micro‐veneering.” Parameters like the extension of the veneering ceramic and its thickness should be standardized in future research to support the comparison of studies.

Other technical complications, such as screw loosening and screw fractures, did not occur in the present study. This finding is also in line with the recent review (Pjetursson et al., 2021), which reported an annual screw‐ and abutment loosening of 0.44% and an annual complication rate of 1.97% for loss of retention. The authors found the highest screw loosening on zirconia monolithic SCs with 2.25% (Pjetursson et al., 2021).

The restorations were adhesively cemented to titanium base abutments in the present study. Several in‐vitro studies showed promising results concerning the stability of the titanium bases compared to conventional titanium abutments (Pitta et al., 2019; Pitta et al., 2021). Loss of retention of the restorations seems to be one critical factor when using titanium base abutments (Koenig et al., 2019). According to the results of in vitro studies (Burkhardt et al., 2021; Dhesi et al., 2021; Zahoui et al., 2020), the cementation protocol can affect the bonding interface stability (Burkhardt et al., 2021). Short‐ to mid‐term clinical studies have also reported promising results (De Angelis et al., 2020; Joda et al., 2017), whereas long‐term clinical outcomes are still lacking. In the present study, no crown retention loss from the titanium base abutment occurred during the 1‐year follow‐up period. This is in line with the results of De Angelis et al., who reported on only one screw‐loosening and no loss of retention of the crown from the titanium base abutment (De Angelis et al., 2020). Yet, this result stands in contrast to the recent review of Pjetursson et al., reporting an overall annual rate of loss of retention of 1.97%, with 4.44% for monolithic zirconia SCs (Pjetursson et al., 2021). In detail, monolithic zirconia SCs presented more frequently the fracture of luting cement compared to veneered zirconia SCs. One RCT showing 1‐year outcomes of monolithic zirconia posterior restorations on titanium base abutments reported one de‐cementation of restoration from its' titanium base abutment, resulting in a 2.3% de‐cementation rate at 1 year (Derksen et al., 2021). Consequently, more research, especially long‐term studies and a longer follow‐up of the present study, are needed to clinically further evaluate the titanium base abutments.

sec.title: CONCLUSION
sec.p: Buccally micro‐veneered lithium disilicate and zirconia implant‐supported SCs exhibit good short‐term performance in anterior and premolar regions. The ceramic type does not seem to impact biological parameters; hence both materials may be recommended for single implant‐borne restorations.
However, the chipping of the veneering ceramic remains the predominant technical problem, even at micro‐veneering. Standardized criteria for micro‐veneering need to be developed.
At the abutment level, titanium base abutments showed promising short‐term clinical results with no de‐cementations of restorations.
Further clinical studies are needed to evaluate buccally micro‐veneered and monolithic crown designs and the use of titanium base abutments on a long‐term scale.

sec.title: AUTHOR CONTRIBUTIONS

Ana Todorovic: Data curation (equal); writing – original draft (supporting). Vincent Fehmer: Conceptualization (supporting); data curation (supporting); resources (lead). Philippe Mojon: Conceptualization (supporting); formal analysis (lead); methodology (supporting); writing – original draft (supporting). Irena Sailer: Conceptualization (equal); formal analysis (supporting); funding acquisition (lead); investigation (supporting); methodology (equal); project administration (supporting); resources (lead); supervision (supporting); writing – original draft (supporting).

ack.p: The authors are grateful to Dr. Jelena Gavric, Dr. Leonard Brazzola, Dr. Francesco Michelini, Dr. Robin Jaquet, and Dr. Philippe Rieder as participating centers of this multicenter clinical study. The authors thank PD Dobrila Nesic for reviewing the manuscript. The authors thank Institut Straumann AG for financial and material support of this study.

sec.title: DATA AVAILABILITY STATEMENT
sec.p: The data that support the findings of this study are available from the corresponding author upon reasonable request.
